content: Hey @WG-async-foundations -- we having a book meeting? Sorry I'm late.
I've kind of lost track of the status of the book =)
I've got a question. Do we really want to open a book on the new shiny feature like this? :) https://rust-lang.github.io/async-book/01_getting_started/03_state_of_async_rust.html
It's pretty heavy on the negatives
I appreciate the need for honesty, but reading it, it mainly feels like "this is an alpha feature we stabilised"
Heh
In general I would still like to adust some of the ordering of the book; but my branch kind of bitrotted away
I might try to re-do it now that we have a setup (I think?) that isn't based on strict line numbers etc, that made it extra hard to do
@Florian Gilcher I think a PR adjusting the opening to be a bit "sunnier" wouldn't be amiss :)
:+1:
I'm looking over the list of issues on the book

there's not much there -- @Florian Gilcher maybe file an issue regarding intro? do you think you will try to do a rewrite (or find someone to do so?)

@Taylor Cramer are you working on the "surprisingly hard things"?
Uh, not sure where my response went
yes, I am
although I had prioritized the select/join stuff over it, so I didn't do it last week
ok.
(Reminder that if y'all want proof readers you should feel free to cc me. =P)
i18N support, neat :) https://github.com/rust-lang/async-book/issues/26
(cc @Manish Goregaokar ^---)

(Reminder that if y'all want proof readers you should feel free to cc me. =P)

Me too. I've been a semi-professional (i.e., paid but part-time) proofreader since 1962, including thousands of pages of IEEE and IEC standards. (FYI, I accidentally ended up as the final editor for the pre-publication draft of the initial IEEE 802.11 (WiFi) standard.)
